.':■■: Part I] HISTORICAL • In order, to give a complete picture of 'this Department, we deem it advisable;to submit this report in five parts, hamely:..' ';."■>.■ Part I Historical' Part II Public Assistance Part 111 Financial and! Statistical -> . • Part IV V Surplus Commodity Distribution Part V ■ Child Welfare ■ • . T_rt I—HISTORICAL Due to the fact'that prior! to the establishment of this- program, the State did not participate in relief measures, we. believe it would be of interest to explain how such matters were handled by the vari - ous counties of the state and the reasons why a great many counties, due to a lack of funds, are unable tb comply with the provisions of the statutes relative to taking care of their poor and indigent persons. As to why the State felt it their duty to assist the counties in their relief problems is so well set out in Section 1 of House Roll 675 passed by the regular session of the 1935 Legislature, we hereby quote this section verbatim: j '":. "Section I. The public health and safety of the State-and of each county and governmental subdivision therein being imperiled by the existing and threatened deprivation of a considerable number of their inhabitants of the necessities of life owing to the present economic, depression, such condition is hereby declared to be a matter of public concern, state and local, and the correction thereof to be a state, county, city and village purpose, the consummation of which re-' quires as a necessary incident the furnishing of public aid to individ - uals. While the duty of providing aid for those in need or unemployed because of lack of employment is primarily an obligation of the counties, nevertheless.it is the sense of the Legislature that, in the. existing emergency, relief and assistance provided for by this Act is vitally necessary to supplement the relief work accomplished or to be accomplished. locally and to encourage and stimulate local effort in the same direction, - j

"This Act, therefore, is declared to be a measure for the Public Health and Safety and occasioned by an existing emergency. "The provisions of any general, special or local law which is inconsistent with the provisions of this Act, or which limit or forbid the furnishing of shelter, fuel, clothing, light, medicine and medical attendance to persons other than poor persons shall not apply to the relief authorized by this Act." FEDERAL ASSISTANCE At this time we feel that due credit should be given to the Fed - eral Government for the splendid relief assistance received through their various agencies during the past four years. The same will be more fully covered in Part 111 of this report. COUNTY RESPONSIBILITY At the present time and for a great many years in the past, the laws of the State of Nebraska have provided that the care of poor and indigent persons is a charge of the county, and laws have been enacted authorizing counties.to make levies to take care of the vari - ous phases in connection with such matters. At the present time our laws provide that all counties can levy not to exceed one-half of one mill for Blind Assistance. All counties under 150,000 in population shall levy not to exceed two-tenths of one mill for a Mothers' Pension Fund. Counties over 150,000 in popu - lation shall levy not to exceed three-tenths of one mill for a Mothers' Pension Fund. All counties can levy not to exceed three-tenths of one mill for relief to Soldiers and Sailors, their widows and minor children. L. B. No. 374 as passed by the 1937 Legislature provides that all counties can for the years 1937 and 1938 levy an additional one mill for relief of unemployed and indigent persons. Perhaps it would be in order at this time to explain why so many counties in Nebraska are now at the end of their financial re - sources and unable without some outside assistance to take care of their relief problems. First; Due to the continued drought covering a period of several years in many sections of the State, the valuation of real estate (especially farm land) has depreciated to such an extent that it has been necessary to reduce the valuation for assessment purposes. As taxes are derived from levies run against the valuation of the taxpayers' property, it can readily be seen why the counties have had a drastic reduction in tax revenues. In some counties in Ne - braska, the taxable valuation has been reduced to about one-half of what it was ten years ago. 2

Second: Another factor that has contributed to the loss of reve - nue for the counties has been the |nability <sf the taxpayers to pay the taxes assessed against their property and this fact is plainly evi - dencedj-by the delinquent real estate tax j lists as published in each county during thi month of October in each year. NEBRASKA'S PENSION AND ASSISTANCE _A*WS Believing that it will be of inter „t to the public and also valuable reference for thii department, we are.herewith tracing the.history of Nebraska's Pension and Assistance laws from the beginning up to the present time. We find that/the first attempt tc enact a Pension Law was by the 49th Regular Session of the 1933 Logislatiire. . . .■ CHAPTER ,68—ARTICLE 2 • ' Briefly, this vas an Old Age Pension Law to be operated entirely by each county n the State and the funds provided by a head tax of not to exceed fifty cents on.each male and female inhabitant of such county between the ages of 2l| and 50 years. This law required the County Boards to appoint a committee of five members to be called a County Old Age Pension Commission whose duty was to carry out the provisions of this, law. The amount of pension paid to any applicant was not to exceed $20.00 per month. |- The main requirements to qualify were as follows: | I. 1. Must be over 65 years of age. j . 2. Had been a citizen of the I'nited States for at least 15 years before making application. . ' 3. Had resided in Nebraska continuously for not less than 15 years immediately precedirg application or resided Jin Ne - braska's years and contiru'ally the last 5 years preceding application.: . ' •(■' ■'■'. 4. The income of the applicant from all sources was not to ex - * ceed $300.00 per year, j 5. Had no child or any other person legally responsible for their support under the laws of tt 'ebraska.' . j . 11. Pensions to be paid by the County Clerk out of the County Gen - eral Fund on an Old Age Pension certificate issued by the County Oid Age Pension Commission. j 1. Provided for funeral expenses not to exceed $100.00. j 2. Recipients to receive no other relief except for medical and : surgical assistance. ■■>; • . ■ 3

Due to the fact that the funds created by the 50(J Head Tax were insufficient to be of much assistance to the many applicants, this law was repealed by the Regular Session of the 1935 Legislature. PENSION AND ASSISTANCE LAWS PASSED BY THE REGULAR SESSION OF 1935 Senate File No. 137, page 491 of the 50th Session of the 1935 Legislature, was also an Old Age Pension Law providing for a fixed pension of $30.00 per-month to qualified applicants. The main requirements to qualify under this law were as follows: I. A. Had attained the age of 65 years or upward. B. Is a citizen of the United States. C. Has been a resident of the State of Nebraska for 5 years during 9 years immediately preceding the application and has resided therein continuously for one year immediately preceding the application. D. The yearly income not to exceed $250.00 per year for the 12 months preceding application. E. Applicant allowed to have a home and two lots in any city, town or village, or not to exceed a home and three acres outside of any city, town, or village at an assessed valuation of not to exceed $3,000.00. 11. This law provided for the appointment of a State Commissioner of Old Age Pensions to be appointed by the Governor. A. The County Boards and County Treasurer were the Pension Boards in each County. y B. Approved applications were certified to the State Treasurer by the State Pension Commissioner and warrants issued and mailed direct to recipients by the State Treasurer. C. The State Treasurer to keep and maintain a separate fund known as Old Age Pension Fund. 111. The Old Age Pension Fund was to be created in the following manner: A. A tax of $2.00 upon every male and female inhabitant of the State of Nebraska between the ages of 21 and 50 years who is sane and is not a public charge as a poor person. B. By such funds as may be set aside and allocated to the Old Age Pension Fund by the State Assistance Committee from the funds created by Senate File No. 363 and House Roll 4

No. 675 as amended 50th Session Nebraska State Legislature ■'■''-. '.' 1935... . .;;: ].' - C. By such other funds as may be appropriated by the State Legislature.. ;| | Governor Cochran appointed a State Pension Commissioner who proceeded to set up the machinery tc operate this law. Several thou - sand applications were received but ao pensions paid due to the fact that about.this time a suit was instituted in the Courts to test the validity of the State Assistance Fund passed by the regular session of 1935. In September, of 1935, the Supreme Court of Nebraska declared the Assistance Act invalid, thereforei no pensions could be paid and this Pension Law was repealed by tl.e Special Session of 1935. j ;;. STATE ASSIST-NCE FUND A .j: - : • House Roll No. 675, page 508 ojf Session Laws of the Regular Session of 1935. j This law created the first State J _sistance Act and it was invali - dated by the Supreme Court of Nebraska tin September 1935.; This law created a fund of $4,000,000 to assist the counties in taking care of their unemployed and rfelief problems. > Thes4,ooo,ooo fund was to be created las follows: I. A. Extra I<J gas tax from March 1, 1935, to July 1, 1936. B. From State General Fund now on hand. $300,000 malt bev - erage tax already collected frbm brewers and importers under Article I, Chapter 53, C. S. Supp. 1933. C. From State Malt beverage tares to be collected from brewers ■'.' and importers and from Stat j hard! liquor taxes and fees "to be collected from dealers, distributors and importers, $700,000. II.: In September, 1935, the Supreme Court jof the State of Nebraska : declared this law and companion acts! unconstitutional for the following reasons: A ■}..'.. A. The Legislative power of the State is 1 vested in the Legislature subject only to the initiative 'and referendum provisions spe - cifically reserved to the peopl „■ :..]'■ : B. The power of the Legislature to make laws is a sovereign power, requiring the exercise of judgment and discretion which camot be delegated to an administrative board.i C. The State Legislature has no power to delegate any of its legislative powers to any outside agency such as the Congress ■': of the United States. '• ,*'■:"•' ■ I 5

D. A statute which appropriated $4,000,000.00 for work relief, direct relief, old age assistance, assistance to dependent moth - ers and children, unemployment insurance, health of mothers' and children, public health or related matters of security and welfare and public works, especially roads by the use of relief labor, to be expended by an administrative board without pro - viding rules and standards of guidance and leaving the dis - tribution of the fund among the various purposes set out in the Act to the arbitrary discretion of the administrative board is an unconstitutional attempt to delegate legislative authority. This suit was instituted by 23 counties of the State of Nebraska who joined together as plaintiffs and insisted that this Act be declared void for the reason that such counties have so far handled all of the poor relief in each of their counties by their own tax funds and have not, and insist that they will not, ask the State for any assistance, therefore, they will be excluded from any benefits of this State Assist - ance Fund. The counties resisting the enforcement of these laws were: Antelope Cuming Kimball " Saunders Arthur Dawson Merrick Seward Banner Gosper Nemaha Sioux Box Butte Grant Phelps Stanton Cass Hooker ( Saline Wayne Colfax Keith Sarpy The Nebraska Petroleum Inc., also Calvin J. Stover, a gasoline dealer, intervened in this suit on the grounds that the collection of this gas tax was unconstitutional and the one-cent gas tax collected should be refunded to the gasoline dealers. Due to the decision rendered by the Nebraska Supreme Court invalidating the Assistance Act, Governor Cochran called a Special Session of the Legislature which convened October 28, 1935 and ad - journed November 25, 1935. 6

The principal reason for calling the Special Session of 1935 was to re-write the Assistance laws in such a form as would overcome the objections raised by the Nebraska Supreme Court which caused the court to declare the Assistance Acts of the regular Session unconsti - tutional. 8

The new Assistance Laws were then submitted and approved by the Federal Security Board at Washington, D. C, on December 31, 1935. To continue public assistance to the needy Blind for the bien - nium ending June 30, 1939. To repeal said original section and to declare an emergency OLD AGE L. B. No. 376. An Act to amend Section 4, Chapter ASSISTANCE 28, Session Laws of Nebraska, 1935 Special, relating to Public Welfare and Social Security. To provide that pro-rata payments of Old Age Assistance can be made if funds become insufficient to pay the full amount. To repeal said original section and to declare an emergency. L. B. No. 158. Provides that until June 30, 1939, 10% of the pro - ceeds of the tax on motor vehicle fuels imposed, shall be credited and shall inure to the State Assistance Fund. AID TO DEPENDENT L. B. No. 380. Provides that assistance for CHILDREN Dependent Children shall continue through the biennium ending June 30, 1939. L. B. No. 495. Provides that inheritance tax money now in the hands of the County Treasurer or hereafter collected by the County Treasurer up to and including March 1, 1939, shall be credited and shall inure to the General Fund of the County and during said period shall be expended solely for the relief of worthy incapacitated in - digent persons. In accordance with the provisions of L. B. No. 425, Governor Cochran, on May 15, 1937, appointed Neil C. Vandemoer as State Director of Assistance. 12

PUBLIC ASSISTANCE j State Assistance funds are prov ded by State Statute and are supplemented by Federal matching on the basis of dollar for dollar in Old Age and Blind Assistance and fifty! cents Federal for leach State Dollar provided for Aid to Dependent Children. This Federal matching is obtained by complying with the' provisions of the Social Security Act, House Roll 7260, enacted by the 74th Congress, which Act provides that a state must submit a plan indicating in detail just what its policies will be as regards its Assistance Program, and agree - ing to meet all Federal provisions of the above Act in order to obtain such Federal matching. ',:.'.-' ;%/'. ',-\.^ V:V .'. STATE PLAN -j :;:-A-. Following is the Federal Statute quoted Sec. 2 (a) taken, from the Federal Social Security Act, House Roll No. 1.7260, under which Ne - braska State Assistance secures Federal matching of State Funds, -•■•■:..-' ■ ; '.-'• ■■•' ' . .'":■■ i ; ■: :•'■■' •-'' •.-■).'■■'■ Sec. 2 (a). A State plan for old-age assistance must (1) provide that it shall be in effect in all political subdivisions of the State, and, if administered by them, be mandatory upon them; (2) provide for financial participation by the State; (3) either provide for the estab - lishment or designation of a single State agency to administer | the plan, or provide for the establishment br designation of a single State agency to supervise the administration of the plan; (4) provide! for granting to any individual, whose daim for old-age assistance is denied, an opportunity for a fair heaijing before such State agency; (5) provide such methods of administration (other than those relat - ing to selection, tenure of office, and compensation of personnel) as are found by the Board to be necessari* for the efficient operation of the plan; (6) provide that the State agency will make such reports, in such form and containing such information,! as the Board may from time to time require, arid comply with' suchprovisions as the Board may from time to time find necessary to assure the correctness and verification of such reports; and (7) provide that, if the State or any of its political subdivisions collects from the j estate of any recipient of old-age assistance any amount wittj respect to old-age assistance furnished him under the plan, one-half [of the net amount so collected shall be promptly paid to the United States. | Any payment so made shall be deposited in the Treasury to the credit of the appropriation for the purposes of this title. ] (b) The Board shall approve any plan which fulfills the condi-' tions specified in subsection (a), except that it shall not approve any 13

plan which imposes, as a condition of eligibility for old-age assistance under the plan— (1) An age requirement of more than sixty-five years, except that the plan may impose, effective until January 1, 1940, an age requirement of as much as seventy years; br (2) Any residence requirement which excludes any resident of the State who has resided therein five years during the nine years immediately preceding the application for old-age assistance and has resided therein continuously for one year immediately preceding the application; or (3) Any citizenship requirement which excludes any citizen of the United States. In order to carry on the Assistance Program under the new laws enacted by the 1937 Legislature for the biennium from July 1, 1937, to July 1, 1939, it was necessary to submit a new set of State plans to the Federal Security Board, outlining the plans of operation for the coming biennium. These plans were then submitted and approved by the Federal Security Board oh August 17, 1937. The approval of the Nebraska State Assistance Plan by the Fed - eral Social Security Board was made subject to two conditions: A. That the State Assistance would make investigation and de - termine whether the present method of allocation of assist - ance funds on a population basis was disadvantageous to recipients. B. That the State Assistance would enforce personnel standards in the administration of State Assistance in both State and County programs. The Assistance Division of the State Assistance Department has responsibility for the administration of the Old Age Assistance, Aid to Dependent Children, and Blind Assistance programs. A Case Work Supervisor, at the present time called Supervisor, Division of Assistance, was appointed on July 7, 1936, to head this division. The responsibilities of this position are to supervise the Assistance Department, and to see that the administering of the State Assistance Program is carried on uniformly and satisfactorily through - out the state. In order to carry on these functions, a staff of nine Field Repre - sentatives was selected and began work on or before October 1, 1936. The Field Representatives are the a_rr_nistrative agents of the State Assistance Department in the field. Their work is to serve as liaison persons between the State and local assistance offices. "They work 14

under the immediate direction of the Supervisor of the Division of Assistance, and are responsible directly to that office. ..-•'• . Each Field Representative is assigned to a geographical area con- • sisting of from s6yen to thirteen adjoining counties, the number of counties depending upon the size of case load, size of the county,' and travelling facilities! j -I Payments of Old Age Assistance, Blind Assistance, and Aid to Dependent Children may, not be made by the county to a recipient until approval from the State Office is received. Therefore the State Certification Department was created. Their function is to study' and approve or reject all new, rejected, modified, [and cancelled grants for Old Age Assistance and Aid to Dependent Children. Beginning on July 1; 1937,. all new, rejected, • modified, arid cancelled grants for Blind Assistance will also be reviewed in this Department. The 'staff works under the direction of the Supervisor of the Division of Assist - ance, and consists of a supervisor, a staff of five case reviewers, all of whom have had training, in social work and/or successful experience in a welfare agency, and the necessary stenographers and clerksJ •";"--: -■.. : '.j-.,' .': -,-'.. -..,-;;.. |/ ..- -'.' "; | .-. : For each applicant of assistance, the county submits to the State an application, investigation, detailed statement of property holdings, statements of contacts with relatives, medical statements, a budget based on need, in some instances narrative jmaterial in addition to that contained in the investigation form, and [any other material such as correspondence that the local director may consider pertinent! and essential for State action. This material is read and carefully checked by the case reviewers. ■ '.' If the records dojnot seem to merit immediate approval of accept - ance or rejection the local director is asked to make further investi-. gation and submit 'more detailed information. Suggestions may be made to the local director regarding the allowances made in certain budgetary items if jthey seem eitheir excessive or inadequate. If a county seems to misinterpret state policies arid procedures, as shown from the reading of a large group of case records, the certification department may correspond directly, with the county calling their attention to the real purpose of the policy or procedure and copies qf such letters are sent to the field representative. "j •/'.'■ Reviews and modifications of budgets are also read in the Certi - fication Department] These reviews are due every six months on OAA and Blind cases, and every three months on ADC cases. Modifications may be and are made in between times if circumstances warrant it. :' .' ■ I ■''•• '■-—■■ .]- -: "■■- I It is expected that the Certification Department will eventually be eliminated as the personnel and the worlc in the counties is [im - proved. As the first step toward this eleven counties have been selected;to do their) own checking and certifying. This selection was made after a careful evaluation by both the certification department and the field representatives of the work being done in the counties. 15

UNIFICATION OF COUNTIES The State Assistance Program has been carried on by the State Assistance Department, ninety-three County Assistance Departments, and the NERA personnels. The State Assistance was primarily set up to administer A. Old Age Assistance B. Blind Assistance C. Aid to Dependent Children D. Direct Relief E. Surplus Commodity Distribution The Nebraska statutes provide for the county participation in these activities. The NERA has supervised the certification of WPA, CCC, NYA, RA, and Surplus Commodities. In counties in which the County Assistance office administers both the State Assistance Program and the NERA program, the county is said to be unified. Payments were made to the recipients in cash. Obligations were incurred against State and Federal funds; Counties have not participated, financially, in the Old-Age Assistance plan. Payments are not made to persons other than those certified for old-age assistance for rendering services to recipients, nor dp the figures include assistance in kind. > "Obligations incurred for old-age assistance have been corrected to July 1,1987 for all errors in reporting, cancellation ol warrants, additional or over-paymenta, and retroactive payments. The grand total of the disbursements to July 1,1937 will agree with the grand total of the. obligations incurred to July 1, 1937 after the disbursement records are adjusted by the amount of old-age refunds and recoveries which were netted to tho disbursements or earned to the disbursements records as a reduction of gross disbursements. TABLE 6—Old-Age Assistance: Old-Age State Summary for the Period January 1, 1936, Through June 30, 1937, for the State of Nebraska (Corrected to July 1,1937) Amount of Obligations Average MONTH Number of Incurred for per Recipients 1 Payment to ' Recipient Recipients 3 1936 January February 147 % 692.67 $ 4.71 March 8,311 91,805.36 11.05 April 15,110 228,811.33 15.14 May 18,722 275,237.46 14.66 June 20,601 319,091.50 15A9 July 21,054 305,281.56 14.50 August 21,492 315,013.24 14.66 September 22,732 338,934.35 14.91 October 23,324 363,740.33 15.60 November 23,781 394,700.24 16.60 December 24,443 . 423,882.05 17.34 1937 January 25,102 $442,918.62 $17.64 February 25,561 460,218.59 18.00 March 26,139 476,650.69 18.24 April 26,451 483,469.95 18.28 May 26,825 487,604.16 " 18.18 June 26,948 486,078.11 18.04 'Application-] of the individuals included here have been, reviewed by the County Boards and formally approved for Old-Age Assistance by the state office. A grant is made tv cover the needs of only one person. A separate grant may be received by his -spouse or by another aged person residing in the same household. •These figures include payments made to persons approved for Old-Age Assistance from State and Federal funds excluding administration expenses and hospitalizations and burials. Payments were made to the recipients in cash; payments were made usually in the latter part of the month for which the assistance was intended. Payments arc not made to persons other than those certified for Old-Age Assistance for rendering service - to recipients nor do the figures include assistance in kind. Obligations incurred for Old- Atie Assistance have been corrected to July 1, 1937. for all errors in reporting, additional or over-payments, cancellation of warrants, and retroactive payments. These corrections were made to the month for which the assistance was intended. There is no month to month agreement between obligations incurred and the monthly records of disbursements. The grand total of the disbursements to July 1, 1937, will agree with the grand total of the obligations incurred after the disbursements records are adjusted by the amount of Old-Age refunds and recoveries which were netted to the disbursements or carried to the disbursements records as a reduction of gross disbursements and adjusted .for $210 for hospitalization and burials which were included aa regular assistance disbursements. The total amount of refunds and recoveries added back to reported net obligations incurred (before correction I was 52.299.61. These refunds and recoveries are included in the total amount of obligations incurred shown in this column. Obligations Have been incurred on the basis of fifty percent against State funds and fifty percent against Federal funds. Payments are made to recipients by the County Clerks from funds allotted monthly from the State Office. The total obligations incurred for the fiscal years 1935-36 and 1936-37 was $5,894,130.21. 34

A grant is made lo cover the needs of the family but ia limited by the number of eligible children in the family. The statutory limit for an eligible family is ?1. for the first eligible child and Sl2 for each additional eligible child. More than one .-rant is not approved for the same household. The household, however, may be receiving other types of public assistance. Tr.e number of children included here is less than the total number of. children in the households receiving aid to dependent children since there are other children in the families who are not eligible for assistance. Corrections to the number of children re - ceiving aid to dependent children assistance have been made to July 1, 1937, for retro - active payments, cancellations, and errors io reporting in those instances where a case load correction was involved. In the case of refunds and recoveries, the individuals were added back to the net number receiving assistance, before correction for refunds and recoveries. "These figures include payments made to families approved for aid to dependent chil - dren assistance from County. State and Federal funds excluding administrative expenses and hospitalizations and burials. Payments were made within the month, usually the latter part.' for which the assistance was intended. Payments are not made to persons other than those certified for aid to dependent children assistance for rendering services to recipients nor do the figures include assistance in kind. Obligations incurred for Aid to Dependent Children assistance have been corrected, to July 1, 1937. for all errors in reporting, additional or over-payments, cancellations of warrants and retroactive pay - ments. The corrections were made lo the month for which the assistance was intended. There is no month to month agreement between obligations incurred and the monthly record of disbursements. The rrrand total of the disbursements to' July 1, 1937, will afrree with the grand total of the obligations incurred after the disbursements records are ad - justed by the amount of Aid to Dependent Children refunds and recoveries which were netted to the disbursements or carried to the disbursements .records.as a reduction of gross disbursements. The total amount of refunds and recoveries added back to reported net obligations incurred (before correction! was $101.97. These refunds and recoveries. are included in the total amount of obligations incurred shown in this column. Payments are made monthly to recipients by the county clerks from funds allotted from the State Office, and in several counties, from funds appropriated by the county. Howard county appropriated 51.280.50 and Sherman county $63.03 or a total of $1,343.53 for Aid to Dependent Children. The remainder of the payments were incurred against State and Federal Funds. Part IV SURPLUS COMMODITY DISTRIBUTION The first six months of 1937 mark the first period, of commodity distribution under the sponsorship of the State Assistance Committee. During this period the monetary value of the commodities distributed exceeded that of either of the two preceding six-month periods. Schedule A, following, lists the number and contents of carloads of the various food items received during this period, and gives some idea of the volume of work and accounting required. Schedule B, following, shows, in column 1, the total amount spent by the Works Progress Administration in payment, since March 15, 1937, of certified, security wage workers only, for the services of an average of 120 persons. Column 2 gives the amount paid by the State as sponsor of the project, Column 3 shows the amount contributed by the counties as co-sponsors, Column 4 is the total of all costs, as com - pared with Column 5, the total monetary value, which shows that the total of all costs was 17% plus of the monetary value. It is interesting to compare this three way division of costs with any of the various Federal matching of funds plans, and, in eliminat - ing WPA's contribution, the actual cost to State and County is less than 10%. Schedule C breaks down the commodities by kinds, i.e., Food, Clothing, and Household Furnishings produced in fifty-nine WPA Sewing Centers and distributed by this division, by counties. A re - turn postcard is mailed to each County Clerk each month, and made a part of the records of the proceedings of the County Commissioners, for the purpose of keeping them informed at all times on the worth of the commodity program. The average number of cases (families) served monthly over the six months period was 15,342. Using the average number of persons in a case (3.95 per family) we find that an average of 60,600 persons have been served each month. Benefiting, in Nebraska, from the activities of the Purchase Sec - tion of the FSCC are the poultry men and farmers, through the pur - chase of five cars (12,000 dozen each) of eggs, and the dairymen and farmers through the purchase of five carload (40,000 pounds each) of Dry Skim Milk. 80

Part V CHILD WELFARE The Child Welfare Bureau, which, until H. R. 425 was passed in May, 1937, was under the Governor's direction, issued a detailed bien - nial report of the Bureau's activities for the period ending December .'ilst, 1936. This report has been printed and submitted to the Gover - nor. Persons wishing information on the Child Welfare Bureau's activities are referred to this report. This report on the Child Welfare Division's activities is necessarily very brief because of the complete - ness of the biennial report for the period ending December 31, 1936, and the fact that the work of the Child Welfare Bureau has been the responsibility of the Board of Control less than two months. The Child Welfare Division has been given responsibility for the work of the Child Welfare Bureau under the Compiled Statutes 1929, Section 71-2701, and Compiled Statutes Supplement 1933, Sections 81-5715 and 5717; Sections 5714 and 5716 have been repealed under H. R. 425. In addition to this work the Child Welfare Division has responsibility for the activities under the Nebraska Assistance Act, outlined in Chapter 30, Special Session Laws, 1935, with the excep - tion of the Aid to' Dependent Children work, which is handled in the Division of Public Assistance. An outline of the work of the Child Welfare Division under these laws may be found in the State Child Welfare Bureau's biennial report, pages 15 to 48. At the close of the period ending June 30th, 1937, plans were submitted to the U. S. Children's Bureau for cooperating with the Federal government in joint State-Federal plans for Crippled Children and Child Welfare Services. The plans submitted outlined a program with the Child Welfare Division closely coordinated with the Assistance and institu - tion work, and it was planned to give the maximum amount of service to the several counties. CHILD WELFARE SERVICES State and Federal Child Welfare Services are administered as one program, with Federal funds being used to carry part of the ex - pense of the work. The State is divided into districts with a Child Welfare consultant in each district. Five areas in the State have been ct up as demonstration counties. Each of these counties has been assigned a Child Welfare worker to work with the County Board and the other local officials. The demonstration county areas are: Scotts Bluff County, Merrick County, Dakota and Dixon Counties, Lincoln County, and Madison and Pierce Counties, The following is a case count summary of the work of the Child Welfare Consultants during the period beginning January 1, 1937, and ending June 30, 1937. The statistics for part of this time may be found in the State Child Welfare Bureau biennial report. 84
